Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase II: Reconfigurable Wireless Platforms for Spectrally Agile Coexistence
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase II project will involve research on and development of a reconfigurable wireless platform enabling broadband communications in rural areas via secondary access of television white spaces (TVWS) spectrum. The recently ratified IEEE standard, 802.22, is the most promising technique proposed for TVWS operation. Unfortunately, current 802.22 implementations create unacceptable levels of out-of-band (OOB) emissions, greatly degrading the performance of both primary and secondary TVWS users. Current designs also fail to sense the presence of other TVWS users as necessary for coexistence. Such limitations have prevented the rollout of 802.22 solutions. The proposed work overcomes these limitations, leading to a low-cost, high throughput, and robust implementation for the 802.22 wireless regional area network (WRAN). Phase II laboratory and field testing will validate the viability of Phase II developed 802.22 WRAN prototype devices for rural broadband deployment. The activities described in this proposal will significantly advance the community?s understanding of methods to make cognitive radio networks such as 802.22 practical and effective in offering broadband services in rural areas.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project centers on offering a low-cost broadband solution to the 14.5 million Americans who live in rural areas currently beyond the reach of broadband access, while appealing to those in rural areas that have broadband access but are unable to afford the high equipment and service costs of current solutions. Rural communities with broadband access have lower unemployment, higher per capita earnings, and greater educational opportunity. Broadband improves rural area healthcare effectiveness while lowering cost. Public safety, emergency service, and first responder communities also call for high data-rate communications to better predict and respond to natural disasters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This STTR focused on the development and demonstration of IEEE 802.22-based wireless communications prototype equipment. The overall solution is denoted “FarNet” and is targeted to offer low-cost broadband services in US rural areas using TV Whitespace (TVWS) frequencies in 470-698 MHz. Current technology fails to provide these services in many remote regions, but the propagation characteristics of TVWS, coupled with STTR-developed processing innovations, promise cost-effective and widespread rural area coverage. 

FarNet provides Internet connectivity for WiFi devices via wireless TVWS communications links. The FarNet subscriber device includes an Ethernet connection. A WiFi Access Point (AP) connected to this Ethernet connection provides connectivity to WiFi devices within the WiFi AP coverage area, offering broadband services to rural area homes, businesses, schools, and hospitals.

FarNet basestation and subscriber units were developed as part of this STTR effort and evaluated through extensive laboratory and field testing. This testing showed the promise of and challenges associated with TVWS for providing low-cost rural broadband communications. In many test cases, performance was as expected given theoretical analysis and long-range TVWS propagation characteristics. In these circumstances, ORB Analytics’ low-cost, IEEE 802.22-based implementation would offer high data rate communication over large rural areas. However, in many other testing scenarios, significant radio frequency (RF) interference was present in the band. This interference would make it difficult to reliably support broadband operations.  Additional innovation and development are therefore required to overcome interference and provide robust and reliable TVWS products. 

Further challenging TVWS commercialization initiatives are recent FCC actions that may limit near-term investment in TVWS technology. In particular, the Broadcast Incentive Auction threatens to leave very little TVWS spectrum for rural broadband. 

In summary, this STTR highlights the potential of TVWS to provide long-range and low-cost broadband communication in rural areas.  However, before this potential is realized and commercial TVWS communications products are viable, first several regulatory and technical hurdles must be overcome.
